summary: This is an email chain from August 26, 2019, between federal prosecutors discussing a New York Times article about two sisters (an artist and her younger sister) who were early victims of Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell in the mid-1990s. The article details their assaults, their attempts to report to the NYPD and FBI, and the lack of official response, highlighting how Epstein avoided scrutiny for years.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure accused of sexually assaulting the two sisters and other young women. The document details his predatory behavior, including groping, inappropriate massages, and luring vulnerable girls.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Described as Epstein's companion who played a key role in recruiting young women, including using terms like 'nubiles,' and who participated in the assault on the older sister. She also made threats against the sisters.

persons.name: Eileen Guggenheim
persons.role: Dean of the New York Academy of Art
persons.context: Introduced the older sister to Epstein and Maxwell at a gallery show. Later, when the sister raised concerns, Guggenheim did not take them seriously.

persons.name: Eric Fischl
persons.context: The older sister's art mentor. He recalled her calling him in a panic after the assault in Ohio, describing a physical encounter and fear over missing photographs.

persons.name: Bill Clinton
persons.context: Mentioned as someone whose potential visits caused bustle at Epstein's townhouse, though the sister never saw him there. Clinton has acknowledged knowing Epstein.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: The sister recalled meeting him in Epstein's office, with Trump eyeing her before Epstein said 'she's not for you.' Trump has acknowledged knowing Epstein.

persons.name: Stuart Pivar
persons.context: Recalled running into the older sister at a flea market around the time she reported Epstein to law enforcement and hearing her discuss her concerns.

persons.name: Vicky Ward
persons.context: Interviewed the two sisters in 2003 for a story about Epstein. The article was published without mentioning them. She later suggested the editor succumbed to pressure from Epstein.

persons.name: Graydon Carter
persons.context: The editor who decided not to include the sisters' account in the 2003 Vanity Fair article, stating the sourcing did not meet the magazine's legal standards.

persons.name: John Connolly
persons.role: Former contributing editor at Vanity Fair
persons.context: Recalled Carter talking about efforts Epstein made to influence the 2003 Vanity Fair article.

persons.name: David Boies
persons.context: The older sister's lawyer, with whom she is working to support other victims of Epstein.

connections.description: Companions who worked together to recruit young women; jointly assaulted the older sister in Ohio.
Guggenheim introduced the older sister (her student) to Epstein and Maxwell at a gallery show.
Fischl was the mentor to Epstein's victim (the older sister) and advised her to flee after she reported the assault to him.
Epstein's home bustled in anticipation of Clinton's potential visits, and Clinton has acknowledged knowing Epstein.
The sister met Trump in Epstein's office. Both have acknowledged knowing each other.
Ward reported on Epstein for Vanity Fair and later suggested editor Graydon Carter succumbed to pressure from Epstein.
Boies is a lawyer working with one of Epstein's victims to support other victims.

events.title: Assault on the Older Sister in Ohio
events.description: At Epstein's Ohio estate, Epstein and Maxwell began violently groping the older sister over her clothes, rubbing her body, commenting on her features, and twisting her nipples to the point of bruising. She fled and barricaded herself in another room.

events.title: Epstein's Inappropriate Advances on the Younger Sister
events.description: During a movie, Epstein began rubbing the younger sister's hand and then her lower leg. She documented the event in her diary, noting it gave her a 'weird feeling.'

events.title: Topless Massage in New Mexico
events.description: At Epstein's New Mexico ranch, Maxwell performed a massage on the younger sister, having her lie topless and massaging her chest. Epstein was possibly watching.

events.title: Reports to NYPD and FBI
events.description: The older sister reported the assault and art theft to the NYPD, who referred her to the FBI for the assault allegation. She also telephoned the FBI directly.

events.title: Vanity Fair Interview
events.description: The two sisters gave a detailed interview to reporter Vicky Ward for a Vanity Fair story on Epstein. Their account was not published, which they felt left them exposed.

events.title: FBI Interviews with the Sisters
events.description: FBI agents interviewed the two sisters in November 2006, taking handwritten notes that outlined key details of their stories, including the earlier reports to police.

events.title: Epstein's Plea Deal
events.description: A plea agreement allowed Epstein to plead guilty to state charges, quashing federal prosecution. The sisters found this deeply demoralizing.

events.title: Epstein's Death in Custody
events.description: The document references Epstein's death earlier in August 2019 in what authorities said was an apparent suicide, after his arrest on federal sex trafficking charges.

locations: New York City (Epstein's townhouse, New York Academy of Art, West Side Highway)
North Carolina (where the older sister was living in 2006)
keyFacts: Two sisters (an artist and her younger sister) are among the earliest known accusers of Jeffrey Epstein, with allegations dating back to 1995-1996.
The older sister reported assaults by Epstein and Maxwell to the NYPD and FBI in 1996, but no significant action was taken, demonstrating early systemic failures.
Ghislaine Maxwell is described as actively recruiting girls, using terms like 'nubiles,' and stopping cars to approach them on the street.
The sisters' account was provided to Vanity Fair in 2003 but was not published, with the reporter later suggesting the editor succumbed to pressure from Epstein.
FBI files from a 2006 investigation contain handwritten notes confirming the sisters' early reports to law enforcement.
